awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of AI and Software Platform for Cost-Effective Soil Carbon Measurement and Assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/ commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable accurate soil health measurements. The proposed project will develop new machine learning (ML) models for accurate soil carbon predictions. The system will generate a statistically- and agronomically-significant soil carbon sampling design customizable for landowner preferences and the parcel’s characteristics.  The envisioned system will integrate a handheld measurement probe and a cloud-based data analysis and management platform for automated, scalable, cost-effective, and authoritative soil carbon sampling. 

The proposed project will develop a novel machine learning (ML) model for the in-situ prediction and analysis of soil carbon and development of automated sampling plans. The proposed system integrates a soil stratification and sampling plan design algorithm; software integrated with a handheld probe; and an integrated cloud-based analysis and data management platform. The research will address technical challenges including: (1) detecting complex covariates; (2) aligning stratification with soil carbon verification protocols; (3) developing novel digital pedology techniques; and (4) developing machine learning tools able to iterate measurement plans in near real-time. The system's outputs will enable parallel regional models and adaptive sampling plans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Global warming is one of the most critical crises facing the world today. Global warming is driven by excessive heat trapped in the atmosphere by greenhouse gases, particularly carbon dioxide. One of the most effective methods to reduce global heating is to trap carbon in the ground as a solid, rather than letting it be released to the atmosphere as carbon dioxide gas. Several US Government and private agencies offer financial incentives to agricultural producers to incorporate carbon into soil, which reduces global warming while also improving crop yields and soil health. However, there is no simple, robust method to accurately measure and verify the amount of carbon trapped in soil, so these incentives are difficult to obtain.

To solve this problem, Yard Stick has created a soil probe that quickly, accurately, and inexpensively measures the level of soil carbon. In this Phase I grant, the Yard Stick accomplished three main goals to increase the accuracy, regional usefulness, and ability to further improve the Probe.

First, the team developed a novel machine learning model to automatically import information from national data sets and use it to create detailed plans on where to take the most representative soil samples. This rapid and cost-effective system will replace the slow and costly conventional process of experts creating individual sampling plans for each project. 

Second, Yard Stick developed soil sampling models that cater to regional soil variability and other characteristics that have never been successfully modeled before. This advance will enable the platform to be used in all geographic areas and landscape types. 

Third, the team built a process to systematically improve the accuracy of the model, and hence the sampling plans and predictive and analytical ability. The sampling plans and Probe ultimately worked as well as the best-available conventional testing methods. 

The Yard Stick Probe will help mainstream and underserved farmers and ranchers diversify their revenue streams with billions of dollars in carbon credits, creating greater profitability and economic stability. Soil carbon revenue will spur rural development in the US, creating jobs in regenerative agriculture and development and measurement of soil carbon projects.

By incorporating more carbon into their soils, growers also will benefit from increased soil health, higher crop yields, and natural pest management, while decreasing reliance on costly petrochemical inputs and heavy machinery. Agricultural methods based on storing carbon and maintaining soil health will improve resilience to climate impacts, while reducing land degradation, erosion, and nutrient runoff. These benefits are transferred to the general population in the form of improved food security, supply chain resilience, and economic competitiveness of the US. Other ecological co-benefits include biodiversity, clean air, clean water, restored watersheds, and better public health and well-being.

Although farmers are highly knowledgeable in agroecology, implementing carbon monitoring with the Yard Stick Probe provides an opportunity to increase their awareness of climate change science and mitigation. In addition, soil scientists also benefit from these Phase I results, which provide improved models of soil carbon amounts and how they change over time.
